sn52.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā anuruddho sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn52.1:1.2.eng: At one time Venerable Anuruddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn52.1:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmato anuruddhassa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
sn52.1:1.3.eng: Then as Anuruddha was in private retreat this thought came to his mind:

sn52.1:1.4.pli: “yesaṃ kesañci cattāro satipaṭṭhānā viraddhā, viraddho tesaṃ ariyo maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī.
sn52.1:1.4.eng: “Whoever has missed out on these four kinds of mindfulness meditation has missed out on the noble path to the complete ending of suffering.

sn52.1:1.5.pli: Yesaṃ kesañci cattāro satipaṭṭhānā āraddhā, āraddho tesaṃ ariyo maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī”ti.
sn52.1:1.5.eng: Whoever has undertaken these four kinds of mindfulness meditation has undertaken the noble path to the complete ending of suffering.”

sn52.1:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno āyasmato anuruddhassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—āyasmato anuruddhassa sammukhe pāturahosi.
sn52.1:2.1.eng: Then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna knew what Venerable Anuruddha was thinking. As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he reappeared in front of Anuruddha,

sn52.1:2.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavoca:

sn52.1:2.3.pli: “kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso anuruddha, bhikkhuno cattāro satipaṭṭhānā āraddhā hontī”ti?
sn52.1:2.3.eng: “Reverend Anuruddha, how do you define the undertaking of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation by a mendicant?”

sn52.1:3.1.pli: “Idhāvuso, bhikkhu ajjhattaṃ kāye samudayadhammānupassī viharati, ajjhattaṃ kāye vayadhammānupassī viharati, ajjhattaṃ kāye samudayavayadhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn52.1:3.1.eng: “Reverend, it’s when a mendicant meditates observing the body internally as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to originate and vanish—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn52.1:3.2.pli: Bahiddhā kāye samudayadhammānupassī viharati, bahiddhā kāye vayadhammānupassī viharati, bahiddhā kāye samudayavayadhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn52.1:3.2.eng: They meditate observing the body externally as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to originate and fall—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn52.1:3.3.pli: Ajjhattabahiddhā kāye samudayadhammānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā kāye vayadhammānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā kāye samudayavayadhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn52.1:3.3.eng: They meditate observing the body internally and externally as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to originate and fall—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn52.1:4.1.pli: So sace ākaṅkhati: ‘appaṭikūle paṭikūlasaññī vihareyyan’ti, paṭikūlasaññī tattha viharati;
sn52.1:4.1.eng: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive,’ that’s what they do.

sn52.1:4.2.pli: sace ākaṅkhati: ‘paṭikūle appaṭikūlasaññī vihareyyan’ti, appaṭikūlasaññī tattha viharati;
sn52.1:4.2.eng: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive,’ that’s what they do.

sn52.1:4.3.pli: sace ākaṅkhati: ‘appaṭikūle ca paṭikūle ca paṭikūlasaññī vihareyyan’ti, paṭikūlasaññī tattha viharati;
sn52.1:4.3.eng: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive and the repulsive,’ that’s what they do.

sn52.1:4.4.pli: sace ākaṅkhati: ‘paṭikūle ca appaṭikūle ca appaṭikūlasaññī vihareyyan’ti, appaṭikūlasaññī tattha viharati;
sn52.1:4.4.eng: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive and the unrepulsive,’ that’s what they do.

sn52.1:4.5.pli: sace ākaṅkhati: ‘appaṭikūlañca paṭikūlañca tadubhayaṃ abhinivajjetvā upekkhako vihareyyaṃ sato sampajāno’ti, upekkhako tattha viharati sato sampajāno.
sn52.1:4.5.eng: If they wish: ‘May I meditate staying equanimous, mindful and aware, shunning both the repulsive and the unrepulsive,’ that’s what they do.

sn52.1:5.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ vedanāsu samudayadhammānupassī viharati, ajjhattaṃ vedanāsu vayadhammānupassī viharati, ajjhattaṃ vedanāsu samudayavayadhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.

sn52.1:5.2.pli: Bahiddhā vedanāsu samudayadhammānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vedanāsu vayadhammānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vedanāsu samudayavayadhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.

sn52.1:5.3.pli: Ajjhattabahiddhā vedanāsu samudayadhammānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vedanāsu vayadhammānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vedanāsu samudayavayadhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn52.1:5.3.eng: internally and externally as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to originate and fall …

sn52.1:6.1.pli: So sace ākaṅkhati: ‘appaṭikūle paṭikūlasaññī vihareyyan’ti, paṭikūlasaññī tattha viharati;

sn52.1:6.2.pli: sace ākaṅkhati: ‘paṭikūle appaṭikūlasaññī vihareyyan’ti, appaṭikūlasaññī tattha viharati;

sn52.1:6.3.pli: sace ākaṅkhati: ‘appaṭikūle ca paṭikūle ca paṭikūlasaññī vihareyyan’ti, paṭikūlasaññī tattha viharati;

sn52.1:6.4.pli: sace ākaṅkhati: ‘paṭikūle ca appaṭikūle ca appaṭikūlasaññī vihareyyan’ti, appaṭikūlasaññī tattha viharati;

sn52.1:6.5.pli: sace ākaṅkhati: ‘appaṭikūlañca paṭikūlañca tadubhayaṃ abhinivajjetvā upekkhako vihareyyaṃ sato sampajāno’ti, upekkhako tattha viharati sato sampajāno.

sn52.1:7.1.eng: They meditate observing the mind internally …

sn52.1:7.3.pli: ajjhattabahiddhā citte samudayadhammānupassī viharati … ajjhattabahiddhā citte vayadhammānupassī viharati … ajjhattabahiddhā citte samudayavayadhammānupassī viharati ātāpī …pe… abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn52.1:7.3.eng: internally and externally as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to originate and fall …

sn52.1:8.1.pli: So sace ākaṅkhati: ‘appaṭikūle paṭikūlasaññī vihareyyan’ti, paṭikūlasaññī tattha viharati …pe…

sn52.1:9.3.pli: ajjhattabahiddhā dhammesu samudayadhammānupassī viharati … ajjhattabahiddhā dhammesu vayadhammānupassī viharati … ajjhattabahiddhā dhammesu samudayavayadhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn52.1:9.3.eng: internally and externally as liable to originate, as liable to fall, and as liable to originate and fall …

sn52.1:10.1.pli: So sace ākaṅkhati: ‘appaṭikūle paṭikūlasaññī vihareyyan’ti, paṭikūlasaññī tattha viharati …pe…
sn52.1:10.1.eng: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive,’ that’s what they do. …

sn52.1:10.2.eng: If they wish: ‘May I meditate staying equanimous, mindful and aware, ignoring both the repulsive and the unrepulsive,’ that’s what they do.

sn52.1:10.3.pli: Ettāvatā kho, āvuso, bhikkhuno cattāro satipaṭṭhānā āraddhā hontī”ti.
sn52.1:10.3.eng: That’s how to define the undertaking of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation by a mendicant.”

sn52.10:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā anuruddho sāvatthiyaṃ viharati andhavanasmiṃ ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
sn52.10:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Anuruddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Dark Forest. And he was sick, suffering, gravely ill.

sn52.10:1.2.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yenāyasmā anuruddho tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn52.10:1.2.eng: Then several mendicants went up to Venerable Anuruddha, and said to him:

sn52.10:2.1.pli: “Katamenāyasmato anuruddhassa vihārena viharato uppannā sārīrikā dukkhā vedanā cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhantī”ti?
sn52.10:2.1.eng: “What meditation does Venerable Anuruddha practice so that physical pain doesn’t occupy his mind?”

sn52.10:2.2.pli: “Catūsu kho me, āvuso, satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacittassa viharato uppannā sārīrikā dukkhā vedanā cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti.
sn52.10:2.2.eng: “Reverends, I meditate with my mind firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation so that physical pain doesn’t occupy my mind.

sn52.10:2.4.eng: I meditate observing an aspect of the body …

sn52.10:2.7.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ—
sn52.10:2.7.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn52.10:2.8.pli: imesu kho me, āvuso, catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacittassa viharato uppannā sārīrikā dukkhā vedanā cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhantī”ti.
sn52.10:2.8.eng: I meditate with my mind firmly established in these four kinds of mindfulness meditation so that physical pain doesn’t occupy my mind.”

sn52.11:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā anuruddho sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn52.11:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Anuruddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn52.11:1.2.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yenāyasmā anuruddho tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā anuruddhena saddhiṃ …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn52.11:1.2.eng: Then several mendicants went up to Venerable Anuruddha, exchanged greetings with him … and said:

sn52.11:2.1.pli: “Katamesaṃ āyasmā anuruddho dhammānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā mahābhiññataṃ patto”ti?
sn52.11:2.1.eng: “What things has Venerable Anuruddha developed and cultivated to attain great direct knowledge?”

sn52.11:2.2.pli: “Catunnaṃ khvāhaṃ, āvuso, satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā mahābhiññataṃ patto.
sn52.11:2.2.eng: “Reverends, I attained great direct knowledge by developing and cultivating the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn52.11:2.4.eng: I meditate observing an aspect of the body …

sn52.11:2.7.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ—
sn52.11:2.7.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn52.11:2.8.pli: imesaṃ khvāhaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā mahābhiññataṃ patto.
sn52.11:2.8.eng: I attained great direct knowledge by developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn52.11:2.9.pli: Imesañca panāhaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā kappasahassaṃ anussarāmī”ti.
sn52.11:2.9.eng: And it’s because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that I recollect a thousand eons.”

sn52.12:1.1.pli: “Imesañca panāhaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhomi—ekopi hutvā bahudhā homi …pe… yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vattemī”ti.
sn52.12:1.1.eng: “… And it’s because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that I wield the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying myself and becoming one again … controlling the body as far as the realm of divinity.”

sn52.13:1.1.pli: “Imesañca panāhaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇāmi dibbe ca mānuse ca ye dūre santike cā”ti.
sn52.13:1.1.eng: “… And it’s because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that, with clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, I hear both kinds of sounds, human and heavenly, whether near or far.”

sn52.14:1.1.pli: “Imesañca panāhaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi—
sn52.14:1.1.eng: “… And it’s because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that I understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having encompassed them with my mind.

sn52.14:1.2.eng: I understand mind with greed as ‘mind with greed’ …

sn52.14:1.3.eng: I understand unfreed mind as ‘unfreed mind’.”

sn52.15:1.1.pli: “Imesañca panāhaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā ṭhānañca ṭhānato aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānato yathābhūtaṃ pajānāmī”ti.
sn52.15:1.1.eng: “… And it’s because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that I truly understand the possible as possible and the impossible as impossible.”

sn52.16:1.1.pli: “Imesañca panāhaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṃ kammasamādānānaṃ ṭhānaso hetuso vipākaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāmī”ti.
sn52.16:1.1.eng: “… And it’s because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that I truly understand the result of deeds undertaken in the past, future, and present in terms of grounds and causes.”

sn52.17:0.3.eng: Where All Paths of Practice Lead

sn52.17:1.1.pli: “Imesañca panāhaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā sabbatthagāminippaṭipadaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāmī”ti.
sn52.17:1.1.eng: “… And it’s because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that I truly understand where all paths of practice lead.”

sn52.18:1.1.pli: “Imesañca panāhaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā anekadhātunānādhātulokaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāmī”ti.
sn52.18:1.1.eng: “… And it’s because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that I truly understand the world with its many and diverse elements.”

sn52.19:1.1.pli: “Imesañca panāhaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā sattānaṃ nānādhimuttikataṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāmī”ti.
sn52.19:1.1.eng: “… And it’s because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that I truly understand the diverse convictions of sentient beings.”

sn52.2:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmato anuruddhassa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
sn52.2:1.2.eng: Then as Anuruddha was in private retreat this thought came to his mind:

sn52.2:1.3.pli: “yesaṃ kesañci cattāro satipaṭṭhānā viraddhā, viraddho tesaṃ ariyo maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī;
sn52.2:1.3.eng: “Whoever has missed out on these four kinds of mindfulness meditation has missed out on the noble path to the complete ending of suffering.

sn52.2:1.4.pli: yesaṃ kesañci cattāro satipaṭṭhānā āraddhā, āraddho tesaṃ ariyo maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī”ti.
sn52.2:1.4.eng: Whoever has undertaken these four kinds of mindfulness meditation has undertaken the noble path to the complete ending of suffering.”

sn52.2:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno āyasmato anuruddhassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—āyasmato anuruddhassa sammukhe pāturahosi. Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavoca:
sn52.2:2.1.eng: Then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna knew what Venerable Anuruddha was thinking. As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he reappeared in front of Anuruddha and said to him:

sn52.2:3.1.pli: “kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso anuruddha, bhikkhuno cattāro satipaṭṭhānā āraddhā hontī”ti?
sn52.2:3.1.eng: “Reverend Anuruddha, how do you define the undertaking of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation by a mendicant?”

sn52.2:4.1.pli: “Idhāvuso, bhikkhu ajjhattaṃ kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn52.2:4.1.eng: “Reverend, it’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body internally—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn52.2:4.2.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of the body externally …

sn52.2:4.3.pli: ajjhattabahiddhā kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn52.2:4.3.eng: internally and externally—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn52.2:5.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn52.2:5.1.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings internally …

sn52.2:5.2.pli: Bahiddhā vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.

sn52.2:5.3.pli: Ajjhattabahiddhā vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.

sn52.2:6.1.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind internally …

sn52.2:6.3.pli: ajjhattabahiddhā citte cittānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.

sn52.2:7.1.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of principles internally …

sn52.2:7.3.pli: ajjhattabahiddhā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn52.2:7.3.eng: internally and externally—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn52.2:7.4.pli: Ettāvatā kho, āvuso, bhikkhuno cattāro satipaṭṭhānā āraddhā hontī”ti.
sn52.2:7.4.eng: That’s how to define the undertaking of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation by a mendicant.”

sn52.20:1.1.pli: “Imesañca panāhaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ indriyaparopariyattaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāmī”ti.
sn52.20:1.1.eng: “… And it’s because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that I truly understand the faculties of other sentient beings and other individuals after encompassing them with my mind.”

sn52.21:1.1.pli: “Imesañca panāhaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā jhānavimokkhasamādhisamāpattīnaṃ saṅkilesaṃ vodānaṃ vuṭṭhānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāmī”ti.
sn52.21:1.1.eng: “… And it’s because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that I truly understand corruption, cleansing, and emergence regarding the absorptions, liberations, immersions, and attainments.”

sn52.22:1.1.pli: “Imesañca panāhaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmī”ti.
sn52.22:1.1.eng: “… And it’s because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that I recollect my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.”

sn52.23:1.1.pli: “Imesañca panāhaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passāmi cavamāne upapajjamāne …pe… iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena yathākammūpage satte pajānāmī”ti.
sn52.23:1.1.eng: “… And it’s because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.”

sn52.24:1.1.pli: “Imesañca panāhaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmī”ti.
sn52.24:1.1.eng: “… And it’s because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that I realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And I live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.”

sn52.24:2.5.eng: The Linked Discourses with Anuruddha are the eighth section.

sn52.3:0.3.eng: On the Bank of the Sutanu

sn52.3:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā anuruddho sāvatthiyaṃ viharati sutanutīre.
sn52.3:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Anuruddha was staying near Sāvatthī on the bank of the Sutanu.

sn52.3:1.2.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yenāyasmā anuruddho tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā anuruddhena saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu.
sn52.3:1.2.eng: Then several mendicants went up to Venerable Anuruddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn52.3:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn52.3:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn52.3:1.4.pli: “katamesaṃ āyasmā anuruddho dhammānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā mahābhiññataṃ patto”ti?
sn52.3:1.4.eng: “What things has Venerable Anuruddha developed and cultivated to attain great direct knowledge?”

sn52.3:2.1.pli: “Catunnaṃ khvāhaṃ, āvuso, satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā mahābhiññataṃ patto.
sn52.3:2.1.eng: “Reverends, I attained great direct knowledge by developing and cultivating the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn52.3:2.3.pli: Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, kāye kāyānupassī viharāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn52.3:2.3.eng: I meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn52.3:2.4.eng: I meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn52.3:2.6.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ—
sn52.3:2.6.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn52.3:2.7.pli: imesaṃ khvāhaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā mahābhiññataṃ patto.
sn52.3:2.7.eng: I attained great direct knowledge by developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn52.3:2.8.pli: Imesañca panāhaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā hīnaṃ dhammaṃ hīnato abbhaññāsiṃ, majjhimaṃ dhammaṃ majjhimato abbhaññāsiṃ, paṇītaṃ dhammaṃ paṇītato abbhaññāsin”ti.
sn52.3:2.8.eng: And it was by developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that I directly knew the lower realm as lower, the middle realm as middle, and the higher realm as higher.”

sn52.4:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca anuruddho āyasmā ca sāriputto āyasmā ca mahāmoggallāno sākete viharanti kaṇḍakīvane.
sn52.4:1.1.eng: At one time the venerables Anuruddha, Sāriputta, and Mahāmoggallāna were staying near Sāketa, in the Thorny Wood.

sn52.4:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ca sāriputto āyasmā ca mahāmoggallāno sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitā yenāyasmā anuruddho tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā anuruddhena saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu.
sn52.4:1.2.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Sāriputta and Mahāmoggallāna came out of retreat, went to Anuruddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn52.4:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavoca:
sn52.4:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side. Sāriputta said to Anuruddha:

sn52.4:1.4.pli: “sekhenāvuso anuruddha, bhikkhunā katame dhammā upasampajja vihātabbā”ti?
sn52.4:1.4.eng: “Reverend Anuruddha, what things should a trainee mendicant enter and remain in?”

sn52.4:2.1.pli: “Sekhenāvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā cattāro satipaṭṭhānā upasampajja vihātabbā.
sn52.4:2.1.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, a trainee mendicant should enter and remain in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn52.4:2.3.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn52.4:2.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn52.4:2.4.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn52.4:2.6.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ—
sn52.4:2.6.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn52.4:2.7.pli: sekhenāvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā upasampajja vihātabbā”ti.
sn52.4:2.7.eng: A trainee mendicant should enter and remain in these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”

sn52.5:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavoca:

sn52.5:1.3.pli: “asekhenāvuso anuruddha, bhikkhunā katame dhammā upasampajja vihātabbā”ti?
sn52.5:1.3.eng: “Reverend Anuruddha, what things should a mendicant who is an adept enter and remain in?”

sn52.5:1.4.pli: “Asekhenāvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā cattāro satipaṭṭhānā upasampajja vihātabbā.
sn52.5:1.4.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, a mendicant who is an adept should enter and remain in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn52.5:1.6.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn52.5:1.6.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn52.5:1.7.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn52.5:1.9.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ—
sn52.5:1.9.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn52.5:1.10.pli: asekhenāvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā upasampajja vihātabbā”ti.
sn52.5:1.10.eng: A mendicant who is an adept should enter and remain in these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”

sn52.6:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavoca:

sn52.6:1.3.pli: “katamesaṃ āyasmā anuruddho dhammānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā mahābhiññataṃ patto”ti?
sn52.6:1.3.eng: “What things has Venerable Anuruddha developed and cultivated to attain great direct knowledge?”

sn52.6:1.4.pli: “Catunnaṃ khvāhaṃ, āvuso, satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā mahābhiññataṃ patto.
sn52.6:1.4.eng: “Reverend, I attained great direct knowledge by developing and cultivating the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn52.6:1.6.pli: Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, kāye kāyānupassī viharāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn52.6:1.6.eng: I meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn52.6:1.7.eng: I meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn52.6:1.9.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ—
sn52.6:1.9.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn52.6:1.10.pli: imesaṃ khvāhaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā mahābhiññataṃ patto.
sn52.6:1.10.eng: I attained great direct knowledge by developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn52.6:1.11.pli: Imesañca panāhaṃ, āvuso, catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā sahassaṃ lokaṃ abhijānāmī”ti.
sn52.6:1.11.eng: And it’s because of developing and cultivating these four kinds of mindfulness meditation that I directly know the thousandfold galaxy.”

sn52.7:1.2.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā anuruddho bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn52.7:1.2.eng: There Venerable Anuruddha addressed the mendicants:

sn52.7:1.4.pli: “Āvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato anuruddhassa paccassosuṃ.

sn52.7:2.1.pli: “Cattārome, āvuso, satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā bahulīkatā taṇhākkhayāya saṃvattanti.
sn52.7:2.1.eng: “Reverends, when these four kinds of mindfulness meditation are developed and cultivated they lead to the ending of craving.

sn52.7:2.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body …

sn52.7:2.6.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ—
sn52.7:2.6.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn52.7:2.7.pli: ime kho, āvuso, cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā bahulīkatā taṇhākkhayāya saṃvattantī”ti.
sn52.7:2.7.eng: When these four kinds of mindfulness meditation are developed and cultivated they lead to the ending of craving.”
